titleStmt.title: A true relation of the late occurrences in Ireland in two letters; one brought over by a noble gentleman, Sir Hards Waller, of a sharpe skirmish there happened the 29. of Iune last, betwixt the Right Honourable the Lord Inchguin, Captain William Jephton, and Sir William Courtney, of the English party, and the rebels on the other side in the province of Munster, dated from Ireland the 8. of this instant Iuly. The other dated the fourth of Iulie from I.H. to his uncle W.E. wherein relation is made of three severall defeats given to the rebels by the Lord of Kelonmikie, the Lord of Broughall, and others. With the taking of 6. ensignes, 8. drums, and armes for 500. men, with great store of bootie.

fileDesc.extent: Approx. 8 KB of XML-encoded text transcribed from 4 1-bit group-IV TIFF page images.

availability.p: This keyboarded and encoded edition of the work described above is co-owned by the institutions providing financial support to the Early English Books Online Text Creation Partnership. This Phase I text is available for reuse, according to the terms of Creative Commons 0 1.0 Universal. The text can be copied, modified, distributed and performed, even for commercial purposes, all without asking permission.

notesStmt.note: Transcribed from: (Early English Books Online ; image set 111394)

titleStmt.title: A true relation of the late occurrences in Ireland in two letters; one brought over by a noble gentleman, Sir Hards Waller, of a sharpe skirmish there happened the 29. of Iune last, betwixt the Right Honourable the Lord Inchguin, Captain William Jephton, and Sir William Courtney, of the English party, and the rebels on the other side in the province of Munster, dated from Ireland the 8. of this instant Iuly. The other dated the fourth of Iulie from I.H. to his uncle W.E. wherein relation is made of three severall defeats given to the rebels by the Lord of Kelonmikie, the Lord of Broughall, and others. With the taking of 6. ensignes, 8. drums, and armes for 500. men, with great store of bootie.

I. H.

publicationStmt.publisher: Printed by A.N. for Edw. Blackmore,

notesStmt.note: Reproductions of the originals in the Cambridge University Library (Early English books) and the British Library (Early English books and Thomason Tracts).

projectDesc.p: Created by converting TCP files to TEI P5 using tcp2tei.xsl, TEI @ Oxford.

editorialDecl.p: EEBO-TCP is a partnership between the Universities of Michigan and Oxford and the publisher ProQuest to create accurately transcribed and encoded texts based on the image sets published by ProQuest via their Early English Books Online (EEBO) database (http://eebo.chadwyck.com). The general aim of EEBO-TCP is to encode one copy (usually the first edition) of every monographic English-language title published between 1473 and 1700 available in EEBO.

EEBO-TCP aimed to produce large quantities of textual data within the usual project restraints of time and funding, and therefore chose to create diplomatic transcriptions (as opposed to critical editions) with light-touch, mainly structural encoding based on the Text Encoding Initiative (http://www.tei-c.org).

The EEBO-TCP project was divided into two phases. The 25,363 texts created during Phase 1 of the project have been released into the public domain as of 1 January 2015. Anyone can now take and use these texts for their own purposes, but we respectfully request that due credit and attribution is given to their original source.
Users should be aware of the process of creating the TCP texts, and therefore of any assumptions that can be made about the data.

Text selection was based on the New Cambridge Bibliography of English Literature (NCBEL). If an author (or for an anonymous work, the title) appears in NCBEL, then their works are eligible for inclusion. Selection was intended to range over a wide variety of subject areas, to reflect the true nature of the print record of the period. In general, first editions of a works in English were prioritized, although there are a number of works in other languages, notably Latin and Welsh, included and sometimes a second or later edition of a work was chosen if there was a compelling reason to do so.

Image sets were sent to external keying companies for transcription and basic encoding. Quality assurance was then carried out by editorial teams in Oxford and Michigan. 5% (or 5 pages, whichever is the greater) of each text was proofread for accuracy and those which did not meet QA standards were returned to the keyers to be redone. After proofreading, the encoding was enhanced and/or corrected and characters marked as illegible were corrected where possible up to a limit of 100 instances per text. Any remaining illegibles were encoded as <gap>s. Understanding these processes should make clear that, while the overall quality of TCP data is very good, some errors will remain and some readable characters will be marked as illegible. Users should bear in mind that in all likelihood such instances will never have been looked at by a TCP editor.
The texts were encoded and linked to page images in accordance with level 4 of the TEI in Libraries guidelines.

Copies of the texts have been issued variously as SGML (TCP schema; ASCII text with mnemonic sdata character entities); displayable XML (TCP schema; characters represented either as UTF-8 Unicode or text strings within braces); or lossless XML (TEI P5, characters represented either as UTF-8 Unicode or TEI g elements).
Keying and markup guidelines are available at the Text Creation Partnership web site.

keywords.term: Ireland -- History -- Rebellion of 1641 -- Early works to 1800.

div.p: A TRVE RELATION Of the late Occurrences in Jreland in two Letters; One brought over by a Noble Gentleman, Sir Hards Waller, of a Å¿harpe SkirmiÅ¿h there happened the 29. of Iune laÅ¿t, betwixt the Right Honourable the Lord Inchguin, Captaine William Jephton, and Sir William Courtney, of the EngliÅ¿h party, and the Rebels on the other Å¿ide in the Province of MunÅ¿ter, Dated from Ireland the 8. of this inÅ¿tant Iuly.
The other Dated the fourth of Iulie from I.H. to his Uncle W.E. wherein Relation is made of three Å¿everall Defeats given to the Rebels by the Lord of Kelonmikie, the Lord of Broughall and others.
With the taking of 6. EnÅ¿ignes, 8. Drums, and Armes for 500. men, with great Å¿tore of Bootie.
LONDON, Printed by A.N. for Edw. Blackmore.

div.head: A true Relation brought over by a Noble Gentleman Sir Hards Waller by name, of a Å¿harpe SkirmiÅ¿h which there happened on the 29. day of June 1642. Betwixt the Right Honourable the Lord Inchguin, Captaine William Iephton, and Sir William Courtney, on the EngliÅ¿h party, and the Rebels on the other Å¿ide, in the Province of MunÅ¿ter.
div.p:
IT happened that the Enemy lying within Å¿even or eight miles of our EngliÅ¿h quarter at Downarayle aforeÅ¿aid; and conÅ¿iÅ¿ting of about twenty five hundred foot, and a Troope of HorÅ¿e, had a DeÅ¿igne (as wee knew by good intelligence) to confront our Forces there, if not to fall foule with us. The Å¿aid Lord Inchguin with the adviÅ¿e of the other Commanders, reÅ¿olved by way of prevention, to march away towards them all night from Downarayle, which enterpriÅ¿e they Å¿o dexterouÅ¿ly purÅ¿ued, that with five hundred MuÅ¿quetiers, and two hundred HorÅ¿e; they were ready to give them a BreakfaÅ¿t the next morning very early: and albeit thoÅ¿e Rebels had gotten Å¿ome private advertiÅ¿ement of our comming, and had therefore Å¿tood all that night to their Armes. Yet did our Å¿aid Commanders find the meanes to approach them; and to trye their mettle, began to Å¿alute them with a Volley of Å¿hot, which Å¿econded by our forward
Troopes did Å¿o daunt them at the very firÅ¿t encounter, that they preÅ¿ently were Rowted, and betooke them with all poÅ¿Å¿ible diligence to their heeles, towards a Wood and Bogge, about halfe a mile off from that place. And our valiant Troopes then purÅ¿uing them, did through Gods eÅ¿peciall favour leÅ¿Å¿en their number by about Å¿ixe hundred men, and tooke Å¿ome of their Commanders PriÅ¿oners, with five of their Colours; they have hereby alÅ¿o augmented their Å¿tore of Armes with many MuÅ¿quets, and many more Pykes in this Conflict which I may Å¿ay, was a very Å¿harpe one on their Å¿ide, but miraculouÅ¿ly favourable on ours. As having loÅ¿t but one man, nor any hurt but one Sergeant, (thankes to the Lord of HoaÅ¿ts.) This and the like Å¿trange Victories wee now and then obtain againÅ¿t the Rebels, doe give us no Å¿mall heart and courage amidÅ¿t the great wants we often undergoe in this now almoÅ¿t deÅ¿olate Countrey; And makes our men goe on with Å¿uch incredible reÅ¿olution, as we reade of the old Romans amongÅ¿t the Barbarous Nations, without being any more daunted with the preÅ¿ent diÅ¿tractions betwixt the King and Parliament, then were thoÅ¿e Romans abroad, when their Emperours and ConÅ¿uls brought the Scene of warre within the Walls of Rome.

It hath pleaÅ¿ed God nevertheleÅ¿Å¿e to temper our late Triumph with Å¿ome Å¿orrow. For upon the fourth of Iuly laÅ¿t, our moÅ¿t Noble and never-enough lamented Sir William Leger, PreÅ¿ident of this Province is departed this life, dying in his bed, of an infirmity which his PhiÅ¿itian Å¿ayes was occaÅ¿ioned by this reÅ¿tleÅ¿Å¿e care and Å¿tudy in his Charge.

Wee daily are put in hope of freÅ¿h Å¿upplyes out of England but they are Å¿o long a comming, that wee begin to
doubt there is Å¿ome power doth maligne the maine DeÅ¿igne, God Å¿end us Å¿ome good newes of an Accommodation of the great Differences in England; And then wee Å¿hall have a redoubled courage againÅ¿t all dangers and difficulties here.

div.head: To my loving Vncle MaÅ¿ter VV. E.
div.p: HAving the conveniency of Å¿ending by this Bearer, I am bold to write of our laÅ¿t Occurrences in theÅ¿e parts.

The 29 of June, wee marched with our EngliÅ¿h forces being four hundred foot, and four Troops of HorÅ¿e towards the Enemy, and having diÅ¿covered them, wee found them to be three thouÅ¿and Foot and HorÅ¿e, and yet we gave them battail, and Å¿uch was the goodneÅ¿Å¿e of God unto us that wee forced them to retreat into a Town, where continuing our purÅ¿uit beat them out again, and forced them utterly to flight, in this Å¿ervice our HorÅ¿e and Foot killed Å¿ix hundred of them, took their Ammunition
and Waggons, & having pillaged their Town, we burnt it to the ground, and brought away Å¿ix EnÅ¿ignes, eight Drums, and took Arms for five hundred men, had we been furniÅ¿hed with Å¿ufficient forces, wee might have Å¿aved the Town and left a GarriÅ¿on in it, which (through Gods aÅ¿Å¿iÅ¿tance might have much advanced the Å¿ervice.

The 30 of June, my Lord Keloumikie, (Å¿on to the Earle of Gork) his HorÅ¿e being in number but 38, marcht out of Bandonbridge, and in the compaÅ¿Å¿e of Å¿ix miles brought in a thouÅ¿and Å¿heep and foure hundred head of Cattle, but in their return, the Rebels (being one thouÅ¿and Å¿trong) were got between our men and the Towne, yet they kept their pray, brought it into the Town, and kild threeÅ¿core and ten of the Rogues with the loÅ¿Å¿e of two men.

The third day of July, my Lord of Broughall marched out to relieve Sir Philip Percivals CaÅ¿tle, with his owne troop onely, and two hundred and fifty foot, and was encountred by a thouÅ¿and of the Rebels horÅ¿e and foot, who after a fierce aÅ¿Å¿ault kill'd one hundred of the Rebels, and relieved the CaÅ¿tle, and in their returne skirmiÅ¿hed againe with the Rogues, and kill'd one hundred and fifty more of them, with the loÅ¿Å¿e of two men onely, bleÅ¿Å¿ed be God who putteth courage into the hearts of our men, teaching their hands to warre, and their fingers to fight, and giveth them victory, wee have taken of late many brave CaÅ¿tles with much proviÅ¿ion.

Surely according to theÅ¿e experiments of Gods wonderfull aÅ¿Å¿iÅ¿tance to our poore forces, it may well be hoped that if we had money to pay our Souldiers, five thouÅ¿and foot with a proportionable number of horÅ¿e would enable us to bid our friends welcome, and to repell enemies, and therefore I earneÅ¿tly beg of God to compoÅ¿e the unhappy
diÅ¿tractions of England, that the wiÅ¿hed, and long expected aÅ¿siÅ¿tance may come.

This morning wee have intelligence that my Lord PreÅ¿ident of MunÅ¿ter is dead, and now my Lord of Corke Å¿ends a Å¿hip to certifie the State of England, by which this is conveyed, I have not time, and therefore crave pardon for not expreÅ¿sing the paÅ¿Å¿ages more at large.
Thus with my duty and beÅ¿t reÅ¿pects to you, and the reÅ¿t of my friends I remayn;
